text: the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of these new Ka
albums languish arts and woeful studies
Brownsville rapper Ka is back adding to
his dense his dark and his verbose
discography with two new albums which he
dropped back to back this past fall each
of them being 10 tracks and running just
under 30 minutes and both given
ingenious education themed titles Kaz
last full-length LP and martyrs reward
in many ways was a tribute to his
consistency as on this thing he offered
more simple skeletal often drumless
instrumentals sound tracking patient and
Smoky verses featuring some of the best
wordplay you are going to hear anywhere
the issue with the album though if you
can even call it an issue is that it was
good but maybe not great Ka kind of
working at his usual level of quality
but not exactly reaching for the Stars
which I guess I could appreciate in a
sense sense the fact that he's sticking
to his guns because he's maybe only one
of a few rappers out there doing
something along these lines and doing it
incredibly well still though going into
these new LPS I was kind of hoping for a
new sound direction or something to keep
things interesting and I suppose in a
way these records are a step in the
right direction the production somehow
more abstract and experimental than it
is on your average car record on some
key tracks be that through the cycling
arpeggios tweeting birds and strange
vocal samples popping up here and there
that sound like a fever dream on the
track building there's also the
endlessly droning and wailing tone on
the track touche which is top of these
dramatic little woodwind licks we also
have the weirdly cluttered instrumental
on WE herding which I'm not in love with
but it does sound different with its
clinks and clanks and noisy guitar
picking as well as twittering mechanical
percussion the Reverb soaked classical
guitar licks on full Cobra are simple
but beautiful and stunning and then
there's the pumping and warped string
surrounded by all these strange wash
sound effects on ascension that feels
like some kind of plunder phonics
experiment from 10 tricks point never
moments like these across these two Ka
albums are interesting and occasionally
gripping but many of the instrumental
backdrops on these albums consist of
very thin keys and piano and guitars
like something super moody out of a Noir
film soundtrack which is fine but I
don't think adds all that much to cause
General instrumental Canon there's more
of an emphasis on choruses with some of
these tracks too like the eerily sung
calls of if it ain't true
it ain't for me on if not true which
aren't exactly Snappy but are still a
huge change of pace for a guy who's not
really big on melodic choruses there are
some more chilling group vocals on the
still holding though I will say The
Melodies they deliver on this cup
particularly are kind of grading not to
mention their mixing and placement
leaves a lot to be desired too because
they're a little quiet and dull and they
dip in and out of cause versus kind of
unceremoniously and another interesting
switch up we have Chuck strangers of pro
airfame featured on the cut unindulged
and a feature on a car album is a rare
sight he also appears on the woeful
studies track counted out too where his
vocal and lyrical performance hit a lot
harder mostly because they play into the
dejected Vibes of the instrumental so
well however with unindulged this is the
shortest track on the first of these two
car records and it feels like it it's a
bit faster than many of the songs
surrounding it but uh you know it's it's
not enough to make a night and day
difference in terms of like excitement
structurally there isn't too much to the
track either I guess I wouldn't expect
so much from it if the chemistry between
caught and Chuck was like super high or
super crazy but it's not really while
yes this track does provide some
versatility to the track list it's
really the starkest and most dramatic
moments on this LP where kozbars hit the
hardest like when he's rapping over the
Deep droning bass and flavorful upright
Baseline clicks all over I'm tired or on
the song touche I mentioned earlier
where he raps hard-boiled the Deep hate
as a Keepsake hope the bandage lasts
from the damage past I can't reshape was
just saving the push kick flip wasn't a
cheapskate all assassins things after
the king trying to seek mate he loves
those chess references these on
obstacles as well I think is a great
example of the general lyricism across
these two records this one is off of
woeful studies but there is a larger
idea I think thematically at play with
the language arts record at least
there's a handful of tracks with vocal
Snippets to boot that seem to focus on
things like learn Behavior there are
bars on these tracks that reflect on
lessons messages and perspectives handed
down from Elders or the classroom the
song Ascension at least in part deals in
becoming less sensitive and caring in
order to be more of a man when these
angles do show up on language arts they
hit pretty hard and they add a new
Dynamic to to cause usual topical Focus
but sadly it's not fully explored or at
least as deeply explored as it could be
throughout the entire LP combine that
with the fact that this record is pretty
scant being under 30 minutes which I
guess you could view it within the
context of woeful studies which it was
released with in in tandem but 20 cuts
across two kind of bare bones records
just isn't that exciting of a prospect
to me I think whittling the songs down
by a third and just keeping it to the
cuts that have the strongest
instrumentals and and verses or maybe
could have used a bit more fleshing out
would have been the stronger statement
because ultimately the double album
release I felt was more exciting in
concept than it was in practice now
there has been some discussion about the
separation between these two records
which one's more experimental or
aggressive than the other I mean if such
a judgment can be made it is by the most
subtle of degrees what is clear going
into woeful studies is that Ka continues
to wax poetic on things like black power
black struggle economic inequity and the
way that his neighborhood has been left
behind in the American scheme there are
some good highlights to come on this
record too be that the block which
explores painting a cause neighborhood
as a threat to existence making mention
of the various people whose lives it
claims he hits us with some speedier
than usual flows on the opening cut
which is a relatively hard-hitting also
matched with a really clever refrain we
in a sent we into Dollars obstacles that
I mentioned earlier has some of the best
writing on these two LPS and my only
home I think is the much stronger of the
two closers on these records just based
on content alone where Ka lyrically
explores his love-hate relationship for
where he's from while he is pained by
the trauma that it's brought him really
to the point where he's wanting to burn
it down still though it's his only home
and it's the place he's known so while I
think these two records together provide
a decent one-two punch a pretty strong
statement that statement could have been
made a lot harder and a lot heavier
heavier had these two records been
paired down to their most essential
moments I think feeling a light to
decent seven on these records transition
